ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course taught me so much about James Baldwin but more importantly about being a human being and about America!
Insight into the life and writing of James Baldwin, one of the most compelling voices of the last century.

I learned how to read, listen to, and talk about James Baldwin. I also learned a lot about the political, social, racial, gender, and sexuality dynamics throughout the 20 years (roughly 1960 to 1980) we covered in the course. Through the weekly reading responses, I was able to delve deeply into a passage or several passages in the text we were covering that week and explore the ideas that had the biggest emotional impact on me. The midterm paper and final project allowed me to explore these ideas even further. Our class discussions, while virtual, were always engaging, well-paced, and balanced. Honestly, it's hard to sum up what skills I developed--it was just such a lovely course. I looked forward to and enjoyed every single reading and class meeting. There is so much to learn from Baldwin.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is one of the best classes out there. Everything James Baldwin writes is amazing but I was appreciative that we read so much of his non-fiction, especially because of everything that was going on in the world this semester. Professor Mirakhor puts so much thought into her selections and would change the syllabus based on our conversations.
A phenomenal course about a phenomenal writer taught by a phenomenal professor.

No weaknesses! Truly, every part of the course was well balanced. A huge strength is definitely Professor Mirakhor, who is a great moderator in discussions, possesses a wealth of info about Baldwin, and offers her time for private meetings with students generously. By constantly pushing me to refine my ideas, she has helped me think and write better.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small size of this course and how dedicated each student was made this a great experience! Sometimes the logistics of the class fell through the cracks, but in the end this wasn't such a big deal.
Honest discussion of the Zoom format was refreshing, and I especially liked the idea of having all participants unmute themselves to salvage a kind of seminar spontaneity.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Everyone should read these books and it is a privilege to get to read them with Professor Mirakhor!
Yes  a must take for students looking for an author centered course in American Studies

Yes! Please take it if you have the opportunity, especially if during shopping period it looks like the class will be small. We were only six students and one professor, and I found this size to be perfect, at least for online learning. We had plenty of opportunities to voice our thoughts in each class meeting. It is one of my favorite classes, if not my favorite class, I've taken at Yale.
